title: PCT 07: How Sweet-Grass became chief. Second Version
author: Simon Mimikwas

sentences.original: wîhkasko-kisêyin kîtahtawê êh-nipât, ohtawâkâhk sakimêsah kitoyiwah :
sentences.text: wîhkasko-kisêyin kîtahtawê ê-nipât ohtawakâhk sakimêsa kitoyiwa
sentences.english: Once upon a time when Sweet-Grass slept, a mosquito spoke into his ear:
“Indeed, too pitiable is thy state.
Four nights from now I shall give it thee; I shall give thee chieftainship.
Too pitiable is thy plight in thy longing to be a chief.”
Then he awoke.
As he awoke, a mosquito flew up from his ear.

sentences.original: mitonih ê-mihcêtikih mîkiwâhpah êwak ôtah natimihk.
sentences.text: mitoni ê-mihcêtiki mîkiwâhpa êwako ôta natimihk
sentences.english: This was in a place where there were many tents, here in the west.

sentences.original: êkosi ê-nisto-tipiskâyik ,-- kayâs môsasiniyah wâwiyêyâwa ,-- êkonih ê-mâh-môhkotahk, opâskisikanihk ê-âh-asiwatât, ê-tâ-tâpiskopayiyikih nôhtaw.
sentences.text: êkosi ê-nisto-tipiskâyik kayâs môsasiniya wâwiyêyâwa êkoni ê-mâh-môhkotahk opâskisikanihk ê-âh-asiwatât ê-tâ-tâpiskopayiyiki nôhtaw
sentences.english: So when three nights had passed, - the old time bullets were round, - these he was shaping, putting them into his gun to fit them beforehand.
Then his brother-in-law came into the lodge.
“Where are you planning to go?” his brother-in-law asked him.
“Early in the morning I mean to ride away,” he answered his brother-in-law.
He tethered his horse outside the lodge.
“Do not leave me behind.
I want to go with you,” said his brother-in-law.
So, when night came, they lay down.
Early in the morning he got up.

sentences.original: namoya miton êh-wâpaniyik, anohc kâ-kîsikâk êkwah kik-ôh-nisitawêyihtâkosin, anohc kâ-kîsikâk.
sentences.english: When it had not yet dawned much, “For this day thou shalt be renowned.”
His horse was fleet.
Some young lads made ready.
He went and gave the word to his brother-in-law.
So they made ready; they rode away.
Far to the south dawn came, as they sat on a small eminence.
Suddenly they saw one who was crawling up a hill.
Presently  that person lay down and hammered.
“Plainly he is not of our comrades.
Let me go there.”
He left his horse there.
He came upon the other from the rear.
Then, “Who are you? I mean to shoot you,” he said to him.
The other threw himself to roll downhill.
Then he shot at him, but missed him.
The other fled into the brush.
Then he called out to his brother-in-law.
The two rode off, to go and tell it.
But he kept the other in sight; he mounted;
the other was fleeing.
He kept watching him; wherever he caught sight of him, he shot at him.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê têpwâtêw, mîkiwâhpihk, mîkiwâhpihk k-êtâmoyin, itêw.
sentences.english: Presently he called out to him, “To the tent, to the tent is where you are running to escape,” he said to him.
The other reached a creek.
When they looked there, they saw a great many people.
They fled; they crossed the creek.
One hid among the trees.
Another dived downstream.
The others crossed.
They fled into the woods; up a slope, like this, they fled into the woods.
The Cree arrived in the same way.
Soon there were many of them.
The Blackfoot made a trench and breastworks.

sentences.original: pêyik êkotah ayahciyiniw okimâwiw; êwakôw kîskihkomân siyihkâsôw.
sentences.text: pêyak êkota ayahciyiniw okimâwiw êwako kîskihkomân isiyîhkâsôw
sentences.english: One of the Blackfoot there was a chief; he was called Cut-Knife.
So they surrounded them.
Then soon they fought.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê pêyak nêhiyaw : otêh ohci wiyacâwiwak.
sentences.english: Presently a Cree called out, “They are escaping over here.”
Then the men whooped.
The others shot at them, but they would not halt.

sentences.original: pêyak câpês siyihkâsôw; pêyak waskasiw-awâsis isiyihkâsôw, êh-osîmihtocik.
sentences.text: pêyak câpês isiyîhkâsôw pêyak waskasîw-âwâsis isiyîhkâsôw ê-osîmihtocik
sentences.english: One man was named Chapess, another Claw-child; they were brothers.

sentences.original: êkosi tâpwê, ispîh manihkomânêk! itwêwak nêhiyawak.
sentences.english: Then, “Get ready your knives!” said the Cree.
Before the cry had gone forth, they leaped up.
They grappled with the Blackfoot.
They used their knives, trying to stab them.
Some they did not stab.
They scalped them; they took their scalps.

sentences.original: êkos îsi ê-kîh-otinahkik, êkosi êkwah tahkamêwak êkwêyâk.
sentences.text: êkosi isi ê-kî-otinahkik êkosi êkwa tahkamêwak êkwêyâk
sentences.english: Only then, when they had taken these, did they stab them.
So they killed them all.
Then they went home.
First they counted them: twenty-two;
they killed all of those at whom they had whooped; they exterminated them.
So, when they had returned home, they made a great celebration.
On account of this Sweet-Grass became a chief.
[no translation, paraphrase of next sentence: All the time since then, to this very day, he is chief.]

sentences.original: êyâpic iskoh kêy-askîwik, êyâpic anohc kîsikâw okimâwiw.
sentences.text: êyâpic isko kê-askîwik êyâpic anohc kîsikâw okimâwiw
sentences.english: All the time since then, to this very day, he is chief.

sentences.original: êwakô kat-nayip k-êsiyihkâtêk, êwakô kîskihkomân kâ-kîh-mêscihiht.
sentences.text: êwako kat-nayip kâ-isiyîhkâtêk êwako kîskihkomân kâ-kî-mêscihiht
sentences.english: The place that is called “Cut-Knife” in English, that is where Chief Cut-Knife and his band were all slain.

sentences.original: âtah ê-kîh-nipahiht, êyâpic okimâwiw anohc kîsikâw.
sentences.text: âta ê-kî-nipahiht êyâpic okimâwiw anohc kîsikâw
sentences.english: But although he was killed, yet to this day he is a chief.

sentences.original: êkosî pêyak ana kâ-kôkît sîsîp-ostikwân isiyihkâsôw;
sentences.text: êkosi pêyak ana kâ-kôkît sîsîp-ostikwân isiyîhkâsôw
sentences.english: he one who dived was called  Duck-Head;

sentences.original: pêyik kâkâsôw isiyihkâsôw; êwakô kâ-sêkôpayihot mistikohk;
sentences.text: pêyak kâkâsôw isiyîhkâsôw êwako kâ-sêkopayihot mistikohk
sentences.english: one was called Hider; he it was who hid among the trees;
only these two remained alive.

sentences.original: nîsitanaw âyiwâk nêwo ê-kîh-ihtasicik, êkosi piko nîso pimâtisiwak.
sentences.text: nîsitanaw ayiwâk nêwo ê-kî-ihtasicik êkosi piko nîso pimâtisiwak
sentences.english: Of the twenty-four, thus only two remained alive.
They told the tale when they reached their country.

sentences.original: êyakô ohci nama wîhkâc ka-pôn-okimâwiw, itwêwak sasîwak.
sentences.english: “From that time on never will he cease to be chief,” say the Sarsi.

sentences.original: nêhiyawak têkosihkwâwi, êyâpic okimâwiw kîskihkomân, itwêwak êsah, kêyotêtwâwi nêhiyawak.
sentences.text: nêhiyawak têkosihkwâwi itwêwak êsa kêyotêtwâwi nêhiyawak
sentences.english: Whenever any Cree arrive, “Cut-Knife is still chief,” they say, when the Cree come visiting.
And so Sweet-Grass became a great chief.

sentences.original: êk ôm âskiy oma wîwotinaskêyiwin okosisah otah kîh-okimâwiyiwah.
sentences.text: êkâ ôma askiy ôma wîwotinaskêyiwin okosisa ôta kî-okimâwiyiwa
sentences.english: And here, on this very land, when the Reserve was assigned, his son was chief.
sentences.footnote: LB on {wîwotinaskêyiwin}:  If correctly recorded, then “the taking of land,” i.e. the assignment of Indian Reserves

sentences.english: Little-Man was his name.
It is twenty-nine years since he died.
That is all.
